title: The Wake Singularity — Final Ledger Closure
narration:
The descent from the Wake Cathedra ends at a singular point carved out of stormlight and patient time. The floor is a braided gyre of the four fate rivers you have shepherded since Act One—Loss, Hide, Live, and Win coil into a luminous whirlpool that never stops turning. Every step sinks a fraction into the mosaic, triggering aurora glyphs that echo the promises minted back in 1.1. The air is hot with ozone and cold with vacuum, a paradox the gremlins solved by lacing the chamber with time-dilated vents. Above you floats the Ledger Singularity, a sphere of mirrored ink suspended by consensus alone. It reflects each of you as you were, as you are, and as you might be once the ledger closes.

Around the gyre rise terraces woven from Act Four’s causeways and Act Five’s spires. The Convergence Causeway’s scaffolds reappear as ribbed bridges, the Horizon Crown’s halos hang like ornaments, and every oath from the Wakefront Threshold hums in the walls. Gremlin delegations have pitched command tents between the terraces: dev crews manage recursive deployments, traders monitor liquidity tides streaming in from supportive guilds, whales anchor gravitational pulses, hackers braid counter-rituals against the enemy’s predictive engines, validators notarize every chant, miners keep the floor molten enough to respond, shillers stream the impossible vistas, and meme tacticians broadcast riffs that keep morale at a permanent crescendo. Hidden difficulty tiers flicker as auroral filaments—silvery for steady progress, amethyst for daring gambits, and star-white for the gambles that rewrite endings.

This is the longest wake the chain has ever hosted, and it adjusts to your party every time you breathe. The Ledger Singularity scans the average score of the characters who stride into each round and flexes the challenge to match your combined legend. If you arrive with myth-making stats, the currents stiffen; if you limp in wounded, the chamber throws you lifelines that still demand courage. Every gremlin reminds you of the Act One compact: the vault grades you in light, but you get to choose the subject matter. Some of you will die. Some will hide. Some will live. Some will win. All must be honored here.

Seven scenes brought you to this point; seven lanes still demand service. The Singularity expects ten rounds of orchestration, three more than any act has dared attempt, because the future needs over-preparation. Each lane claims a terrace, each terrace hums with the tools you have earned, and each round layers dialogues so dense they function as choruses. Double-length banter scrolls across the walls as every faction throws in advice, jokes, and improvised vows. The Wake Singularity refuses brevity. It wants the story told twice, thrice, until every player knows the cost of the finale.

Your rules from 1.1 and the councils of Act Four still apply: rolls follow the golden-ratio die, AFK safeties force friends back into play, and consensus remains the pivot. The ledger tallies focus, coins, XP, and flags with ruthless accuracy. Yet the Singularity offers a parting grace. When the ledger closes and you survive to the final vow, each character will receive a Singular Wake Relic—a special item that binds forever to the character’s soul, living in a vault slot reserved for future books. It hums with a 1% resonance bonus to every stat, subtle yet permanent, an echo you can always call home.

Take your places on the terraces. Ten rounds await: mapping, weaving, sanctifying, cloaking, rescuing, arming, braiding, trialing, voting, and finally binding the relic that proves you were here. The Wake Singularity hears your footsteps and the ledger-sphere begins to spin faster.

rounds.description: Singularity Ignition — map, prime, anchor, and bind the battlefield that will judge every fate lane.
